page.title: 18ECOLOGY OF BISHOP BURTON
page.content: Much of the woodland of the area is managed for conservation, the aim being to maintain the greatest variety of flora and fauna. There are 140 different species and cultivars in the area, some individual trees being over 100 years old. Felling and replanting is a common practice and the most common species are: oak, ash, yew, pine, lime, beech, larch, maple, sycamore, hornbeam, chestnut and Norway spruce. The hedges are not species-rich, the main species being hawthorn, holly and rhododendron. There is a variety of fauna- squirrels, weasels, rabbits, moles, voles, stoats aswell as deer, foxes and badgers. Fifty different species of birds have been sighted including woodpeckers, owls, tits, treecreepers and finches. There is a nature reserve in the College grounds with a pond.
